Posts.Content: Hi commoner Very sorry you find yourself on here but you have found the right place for great advice. You've already had some helpful advice but I thought I'd share my experience too in case it helps. I had a mastectomy and an immediate pre pectoral implant last May. I don't know if you are having radiotherapy but there is a risk that the radiotherapy could cause capsular contracture (hardening around the implant) and so some surgeons don't like to do implants before radiotherapy. Mine discussed the risks and we decided to go ahead with an immediate recon. I'll try to answer your questions: 1. I am also small but not quite so small as you - I'm a B. Unfortunately my surgeon put the wrong size implant in so at the moment I have one larger boob (I haven't decided whether to have it corrected). There are smaller implants available. I am using a prosthesis on the other side to even things up under clothes. Not ideal but I have got used to it as a new normal - but I don't wear it when I am playing sport. My new boob is firmer and a different shape to my other one, more round while my original sounds like yours, heading south! (I'm also 50). 2. I don't find my implant uncomfortable. I run and go to the gym without problems. My surgeon did the same pre pectoral implant for a lady who was a triathlete and wanted the least invasive implant so that she could carry on her sport. 4. You will still get mammograms on your remaining breast. 5. You don't have mammograms on your implant. I asked my team how I would know if I had a recurrence in the implant breast and was told that any recurrence would almost certainly be in the skin/tissue above the implant (not sure what is left, probably just skin) and so I would be able to feel it. I think it's a very personal decision and I wish you all the best for your surgery and decision. It depends what outcome you are looking for. Mine isn't perfect but it really doesn't bother me as much as I expected. I am very happy to answer any more questions on here or in a private message if that's easier Evie x

Posts.Content: This is the reply I have received to my complaint about the campaign: "Thank you for your email providing feedback about our Brave the Shave campaign. I do apologise for any upset we may have caused.   Before I begin I want to thank you for letting me know about you’re your breast cancer diagnosis. I understand that cancer affects everyone differently and it’s effects can be long lasting. If you ever need any information, support or even someone to talk things through with our support line is here for you. You can call our support line free on 0808 808 0000 (Monday-Friday 9am-8pm).   In your email to us you asked us why we run our Brave the Shave campaign. It began after we found that thousands of Macmillan supporters were choosing to shave their head and fundraise for Macmillan each year. Originally we launched this as ‘Shave or Style’, however from this campaign, we found that the majority of participants were opting to shave and so moved forward with that aspect specifically. We wanted to provide these supporters with a better platform in order to raise money, while sharing their fundraising activity.   Many people who fundraise though Brave the Shave want to show solidarity with people they know, who have lost their hair through their cancer treatment and feel that this campaign is one way of showing their support. It is through their generosity that we were able to raise £7.1m last year alone. This money is crucial in helping us run our vital services so that we can support more people affected by cancer. Despite this we do realise that this campaign is not to everyone's liking and I can only apologise for how it has made you feel.    Thank you again for taking the time to pass on your thoughts. I'd like to reassure you that all the feedback we receive is reviewed and is used to shape future campaigns as we want to ensure that they are as sensitive as possible. If we can be of any further assistance in this matter please don’t hesitate to contact us on 0300 1000 200 (Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm) or by emailing feedback@macmillan.org.uk.

Posts.Content: Hi Frankie First of all a big hug to you as you go through chemo. How lovely of you to keep donating your hair to the Princess Trust. I just wanted to share what I did when I went through chemo as I too couldn't face a shave. I tried cold cap twice but gave up after that as it didn't really work for me and gave me the worst headaches. It did slow the loss a little and I kept what little hair I had so that I had something, albeit very little, to stick out from under my headscarves (hope that makes some sort of sense). Only when I started to see new hair start to grow did I shave the few remaining hairs so that I didn't have a variety of lengths. I asked my husband to shave it and he found it heartbreaking to do. So when I see the "brave the shave" campaign" it upsets me so much as I it brings back that horrible time for me. It is truly shocking that Macmillan are just ignoring all the comments on this thread and others. Surely a spokesperson could at least acknowledge what is being written. Evie xx
